title: When the assassin reworks come out, can you do something about playing against them?
body:
Because they are incredibly binary.

Two things can happen with an assassin.

They are either dead weight or make the enemy want to kill themselves.

Assassins without escapes either need no counterplay to their combo to be strong ({{champion:84}} {{champion:107}} {{champion:91}}) or they build like a bruiser/tank. Probably the healthiest assassin without an escape is {{champion:131}} and people still complain about how bulky her shield makes her and how insanely fast her QRR is, not to mention the fact that she has crowd control means she breaks the "No CC for assassins!" golden rule some people will swear bye. Why on Earth would anyone ever play a squishy melee champion with no utility and no safety if they weren't obscenely good at killing people?

People need to get some sense of perspective when talking about what assassins should and shouldn't be able to do because posts like this always just end up as "Assassins need to be comfortably the worst class in the game". People talk about how assassins should be just damage with no defensive mobility, no in-kit bulk/sustain, no utility and no poke and think that a class with those limitations could ever be worthwhile when you could just pick a mage/bruiser and keep reasonable kill pressure while having other uses/some chance of not feeding horribly.

the irony of using diana as an example is that she is classified as a fighter/mage, not assassin. 

Firstly, assassins can have CC, i never said they couldn't, but half of ekko's kit seems to just be tacked onto the champion for no reason other than to increase his coverage as a champion, without much thought for balance. Where instead they could've added power or emphasis to other parts of his kit, instead they increased it through means of utility, leaving almost no meaningful holes in his kit for counter play.

Back to your reply though... It's not trying to make assassins the "worst class in the game". It's about which part of the assassin's kit should be left up the the player, and which should be controlled by champion mechanics. I feel that the damage and assassination of the assassins should be controlled by the champion's kit. It should be easier to full combo on an assassin than say a mage. However, they shouldn't be given the escape from the fight, within the champion's mechanics. Assassins should have reliable damage, where as mages have unreliable damage (skillshots), but range to assist in positioning/escape. 

So take zed for example. If zed engages onto you, as it stands right now and how it would remain, is that if you're a mage or marksmen you're likely going to die, however if you move into a position, say under the tower or near an ally, then the zed should also be very likely to die after having killed you. 
Say you were to just remove the return portion of his ult. Does zed loose any of his assassination potential? No.
All he does is lose his "get out of jail free card", when it comes to escaping. So it's on the player's back to either plan an escape accordingly when engaging a target in a fight, or be sure to kill the target who is more valuable than themselves in a team fight. If zed saves his W, he could use it to escape the fight, but that would mean he's making a MEANINGFUL TRADE OFF, of escape potential for damage potential.

Haha actually just look at the comment \/ below, from Tanathalis. He talks about the same thing, overly efficient disengage built into the kits.

I think one of the main problems is that alot of assasins have overly efficient disengage Zed, Ekko, Yasuo ( less so than others but its there ) Leblanc ( Not as bad ) and these honestly are the main ones im referring to. Ekko can dash to his opponent and if it goes bad he can easily ult back out, same for zed. I really think that gives them a very easy life as an assasin, they can just about engage a fight  by them selves and back off instead of picking off carries in the backline after the fight starts.

Maybe if Zed can only R back AFTER he gets a kill with his ulti it might work a bit better, maybe put a short delay on ekko's Ult ( not a channel ) Like after hitting R 1.5 seconds later he goes back so if he dosnt time it right he'll either die or wont get the kill he's going for.

Yasuo's dash has less of the same problems because if he uses a minion wave to get to you, he'll have a harder time getting back out with the dash delay.

Leblanc i think is alright, her snare is a pretty big part of her kit and she cant instantly dash away or she wont get the snare, and the dash range is fairly short.


I think an example of some assasins that are in better spots are Talon,  Kat, and akali, ( i dont mean based on how there performing in the meta, but more about how there kits perform )

Talon has to to his target which puts him out there and he dosnt really have an escape, his ult stealths him but stealth has a few ways to counter it, and its not a instant blink back to safety.

Katarina has to get a kill or assist before shes able to blink again so if she goes in and dosnt get the kill / assist, she's usually left in a very bad spot with her abilities left on cooldown.

Akali dosnt really get early game dominance at all because of how ult reliant she is which is her clear major weakness, and even after she gets it she cant go super crazy, she has to auto attack in her combo unless shes in a clear advantage which slows down her 100 to 0 Potential by quite a bit unless she picks the right targets, her ultimate is a dash and not a blink so the opponent does have a bit of reaction time to maybe zhonyas or barrier, or flash under tower to put akali in a bad spot, and if there are no enemy minions nearby when akali needs to get out, she cant use her ult.

tl;dr I think risk / reward needs to be seriously redone with alot of the popular assassins at the moment.

These are just my opinions, I could be wrong.

Poor waveclear, not much utility to the team aside from the chain, very dependent on creating a lead to contribute to the team, and even if you get fed its often difficult to carry because she excels at bursting one target, whereas other midlaners contribute more in a teamfight.

The issue w/ her is that her point and click QW + thunderlords proc at level 2 will do like 40%-50% health against a champ with low base health and no MR runes. And the only way to really avoid it is to just...not come close to her. This makes it very easy to get early kills and zone out the other laner. She's so oppressive in lane. What the solution to that is? Not sure tbh. 

Zed being unable to jump back to ult until he gets a kill would gut him. Maybe being unable until deathmark would secure the kill.

i think the LB thing comes from a change years back, where they increase the length which her tether breaks to something like double the missile range. Revert that, and she's in a much healthier spot. 

On the point of zed though, i don't see anything wrong with making him wait to return, or removing the return all together. The reason for this is that it's the assassin's job to escape a fight, they shouldn't be given a button which completes the task for them. If a zed dies for the enemy fed MF, then it's still a successful assassination. It's even more justified with the removal of QSS cleanse of zed ult. Although more importantly, it creates an actual meaningful decision. where right now none exists. You either use your W for damage and increase kill potential, or you save it for escape and risk failing to assassinate the target.

So if riot decided to target the areas you were talking about with those champions, they'd have to have considerable buffs on their    damage output. I think you'd slowly be pushing them towards talon and rengar levels of burst where there is very little opportunity of retaliation from the enemy.

Oh and Yasuo isnt considered an assassin by riot though, he is in the same category as fiora, yi, and tryndamere.

Honestly idk if there is a solution to that problem. That's in a way the fundamental role of an assassin, kill the enemy before they can react or die trying.

I think the only way to properly balance them would be to somehow make it so that if they engage poorly, even if they succeed in killing a target, they die. The reason for this is pretty simple. It puts assassin timing and engagement the equivalent of marksmen positioning. Assassins are given to much defensive utility, between their mobility or damage mitigation. If they planned an escape route, then fine, but their kit shouldn't be giving them answer to them getting the hell out of an enemy team.

I'm reasonably certain that if any assassin is apart of the assassin update, this is 90% of what the assassin update will bring.

Assassins have historically had really low counterplay to their burst patterns, and I feel like most assassins would get their burst patterns changed to either have a bigger delay (like Zed) or be able to dodge more of their burst (like Ekko).

Well, when you have an entire class centered around killing people, there's not much you can do for them.
So wait ADC's aren't centered around killing people?
riot seems to want them to be specifically the tank and tower killers of the team. Although at this point, they've strong armed the previous tank killers out of the role, which was mages.
Yeah they are definitely tank killers and tower killers, but they are very very snowball-y right now, leaving them able to take down squishies late game.
mages aren't tank killers. mages are squish killers.

Believe it or not they were. They were given the % damage, a means to more easily kill tanks indirectly. Tanks were initially not intended to be targeted, which is why mages were their counter. The AOE combine with % damage meant they would kill them while also damaging other targets. They weren't as good at singling out targets, because skillshots, where marksmen could auto-attack and assassins assassinate.

some of them were ok, like brand or karthus, but a majority of them sucked at it, like ziggs, xerath, or annie. even the ones that were ok are way better at killing squish than tanks. the tank killing classes are bruiser and adc.
Assassins kill people, adcs kill structures. It takes adcs too long to kill people (with a few outlier exceptions) and they need a lot of team help to do it.

Just to be clear, people will not enjoy playing against assassins regardless of what they do in the assassin update. Playing against something designed to burst squishy champions will never be enjoyable for people that frequently play squishy champions. 

Riot's goal should be to increase counterplay against the problematic ones and ensure playing an assassin successfully requires a certain skill level relative to your opponent, without making them clunky.

That may be a hard thing to ask riot considering the fact that the two assassins that are the least binary with the most counterplay to their burst rotation are arguably the two most complained about champions right now.
